title-group.article-title: Work Socialization and Adolescents' Work-Related Values in Single-Mother African American Families

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Teru Toyokawa is an associate professor of psychology at Pacific Lutheran University, Tacoma, Washington. He obtained his BA and MA in Psychology from Waseda Univeristy, Tokyo, Japan, and his PhD in Human Development from the Pennsylvania State University. He completed his postdoctoral training at the University of Michigan. His current research interests include cross-cultural comparisons in transitions to adulthood, the concepts of adulthood and maturity, and the impact of family relations on ethnic minority adolescents' development. He enjoys running marathons, hiking, and listening to and playing music.

Vonnie C. McLoyd is the Ewart A. C. Thomas Collegiate Professor of Psychology at the University of Michigan–Ann Arbor. She received a BA in Psychology from Talladega College, a PhD in Developmental Psychology from the University of Michigan, and postdoctoral training at Stanford University. Her research and publications focus on the impact of economic stress and work-related transitions on family life and children’s development, the mediators and moderators of these impacts, and the implications of research on these issues for both practice and policy. She has written extensively about methodological and conceptual issues in the study of African American children and families and has a longstanding interest in how race, ethnicity, and culture shape child socialization and development. In addition to her patronage of theater and visual arts, her leisure activities include traveling, gardening, and cooking.

abstract.p: This study examined African American mothers' work socialization messages in relation to adolescents' work-related values. Moderation effects of mother–adolescent relation quality on the linkage between maternal socialization messages and adolescents' outcomes were also examined. Participants were 245 single African American mothers and their seventh- and eighth-grade children. Results showed that for boys, greater frequency of conventional messages (e.g., importance of discipline, hard work, and skills for job success) was associated with stronger endorsement of hard work for success, whereas for girls, this association was found only for those who perceived positive relations with their mothers. Race-related messages (e.g., the notion that African Americans have to work harder than Anglo Americans to get ahead) predicted girls' effort in schoolwork, but only among those who had less positive relations with their mothers. The importance of mother–child relations in the transmission of mothers' socialization messages to children is discussed.

body.p: Adolescence is a period of transition from school to the world of adult work. In this developmental stage, one is socialized to develop occupational interests and values, attitudes, beliefs, and expectations that are thought to ease the school-to-work transition. Work orientations developed during early or middle adolescence are considered important because of their potential to influence occupational aspirations and choices in late adolescence or early adulthood (Diemer & Hsieh, 2008; Goldstein & Oldham, 1979; Mortimer & Kumka, 1982). In his psychosocial development theory, Erikson (1968) proposed early to mid-adolescence is a time when youth come to identify themselves with workers in society, understand the roles of certain occupations, and develop a sense of work ethic and interests in future occupations.

Family is considered one of the most important contexts in which work socialization occurs (Vondracek, Lerner, & Schulenberg, 1986). Within the family context, parental influence is regarded as particularly significant. Super (1957) asserts that adolescents' work-related values and attitudes develop through interaction and identification with socializing agents, particularly parents and significant others. Although there is evidence that adolescents of color from low-income families tend to have lower occupational self-efficacy and expectations than Anglo American youth (Constantine, Erickson, Banks, & Timberlake, 1998), remarkably little is known about how families of color socialize their children for the world of work. The present study assessing the relation between maternal work socialization and adolescents' work-related values in a sample of low-income African American families is a small step toward redressing this gap.

sec.title: Work Socialization in African American Families
sec.p: For a substantial proportion of African American families, familial socialization of African American children into the world of work occurs within the context of several employment-related disadvantages. First, African Americans have long been disadvantaged in the labor market. Compared to their Anglo American counterparts, African American adults typically are twice as likely to be unemployed and are substantially more vulnerable to layoffs and job displacements because of structural changes in the economy (James, 1985; Wilson, 1987). Parallel race disparities exist among adolescents. In both inner cities and the general U.S. population, African American youth are more likely to be unemployed than Hispanic or White youth (Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2000; Entwisle, Alexander, & Olson, 2000). In 2007, 29.4% of 16- to 19-year-old African Americans were unemployed, compared to 15.7% of their Anglo American counterparts (U.S. Department of Labor, 2008). Helping adolescents successfully transition from a student role to an adult worker role is challenging when youth employment opportunities are scarce (Bowman, 1990).

Moreover, parents who are unemployed or have a history of unstable employment may not exemplify the value and rewards of employment as prominently as stably employed parents and therefore may be weaker models of the worker role. These circumstances may have consequences for adolescent children’s orientation toward the future. Prior research indicates that adolescents are more optimistic about their economic and occupational futures if their parents are employed (Quane & Rankin, 1998), if they perceive their families as experiencing less financial strain (Flanagan, 1990; Larson, 1984; McLoyd & Jozefowicz, 1996), and if they perceive their parents as having more favorable work experiences (Neblett & Cortina, 2006).

Another employment-related disadvantage disproportionately shared by African Americans is residence in poor neighborhoods. African Americans who are poor are much more likely than their Anglo American counterparts to live in neighborhoods of concentrated poverty. Living in such neighborhoods may lower adolescents' occupational aspirations, expectations, and choices and even their motivation to work or seek employment because of fewer role models of adult workers/mentors, fewer opportunities to gain work experiences and less access to information about jobs (Constantine et al., 1998; Diemer, 2007; Smith, 1983; Wilson, 1987). For example, Cook et al. (1996) reported that as early as second grade, the occupational expectations of urban African American boys living in poor neighborhoods mirror existing race and class differences in adult job holdings when compared to those of middle-class Anglo American boys.

sec.title: Parental Race-Related Messages About Work
sec.p: The literature suggests that many African American parents emphasize to their children that education and hard work are core prerequisites for upward mobility (Stevenson, Chen, & Uttal, 1990). Together with the emphasis on the value of education and hard work, many African American parents impart messages to their children about racial barriers and inequalities in society and teach or model coping strategies for dealing with negative race-related experiences. This race socialization appears to be a significant part of the child rearing of African American parents in general (Bowman & Howard, 1985; Coard & Sellers, 2005).

Several studies have investigated the types of race-related socialization messages that African American parents communicate to their children (e.g., Boykin & Toms, 1985; Hughes, Rodriguez, Smith, Johnson, & Stevenson, 2006), while others have examined the linkages between parents' race-related socialization messages and children’s and adolescents' outcomes, such as socioemotional adjustment (Harris-Britt, Valrie, Kurtz-Costes, & Rowley, 2007; McHale et al., 2006; Stevenson, Reed, Bodison, & Bishop, 1997), identification with their own ethnic group (Hughes & Chen, 1997), ethnic identity (Hughes & Johnson, 2001; McHale et al., 2006), cultural values (Spencer, 1983), and school achievement (Marshall, 1995; Thomas & Speight, 1999).

Although research on the nature and correlates of racial socialization has burgeoned during the past 15 years, surprisingly little empirical study has been devoted to the nature, extent, and correlates of African American parents' discussions with their adolescent children specifically about employment and career issues. In one of the few studies of these issues, McCabe and Barnett (2000) found that the frequency with which African American mothers discussed children’s future careers was positively associated with the level of salience and detail of children’s thinking about their futures (McCabe & Barnett, 2000).

Notwithstanding African American parents' emphasis on education as a vehicle for upward mobility, low-income African American youth tend to develop beliefs that academic strivings and school achievement will not lead to fulfillment of their occupational aspirations (Graham, Taylor, & Hudley, 1998; Jackson, Kacanski, Rust, & Beck, 2006). Mickelson (1990) contends that African American youths hold dual value or belief systems, specifically, abstract attitudes and beliefs on one hand and concrete attitudes and beliefs on the other. The system of abstract attitudes and beliefs is consistent with the mainstream ideology of valuing education and hard work, whereas the system of concrete attitudes and beliefs is shaped by African American youths' daily experiences and observations of racial discrimination, prejudice, and the unequal opportunity structure. Given this dual belief system, African American adolescents, compared to their Anglo American counterparts, may perceive fewer occupational and financial returns on education. Drawing on Mickelson’s conceptualization, the present study focuses on two types of socialization messages race-related messages and conventional messages that are analogous to Mickelson’s abstract versus concrete attitudes/beliefs, respectively. We hypothesized that both types of messages about work would positively predict adolescents' endorsement of work-related values and that race-related messages would be related more strongly than conventional messages to adolescents' endorsement of work-related values.

sec.title: Mother–Adolescent Relations as a Context for Work Socialization
sec.p: Whether children internalize the values and messages that parents communicate to them is conditional on several factors. Scholars suggest that one of the important factors influencing children’s acceptance of parental messages is the affective quality of parent–child relations (Grusec & Goodnow, 1994; Schulenberg, Vondracek, & Crouter, 1984; Smalls, 2009). Previous studies report a negative association between college students' conflictual interactions with their opposite-sex parents and vocational identity (i.e., having a clear and stable sense of work-related goals, interests, and abilities; Lopez, 1989) and a positive relation between the quality of family relations and adolescents' career planning attitudes (Hargrove, Inman, & Crane, 2005).

Research testing the occupational linkages hypothesis also speaks to the role of parent–child relations in the transmission of parents' work values to their children. This hypothesis states that the characteristics of parents' occupations will result in the acquisition of personality characteristics and work values that are needed to meet their occupational roles, which in turn, will influence their socialization orientations, including parenting practices and parent–child communication (Mortimer & Kumka, 1982). The major assumption in the hypothesis is that the values and beliefs that children consider important for success in the adult world of work are transmitted through relations with their parents who have acquired those values and beliefs in meeting their occupational demands. Testing this occupational linkage hypothesis, Mortimer and Kumka found a statistically significant and positive relation between sons' reports of supportive relations with their fathers and sons' endorsement of their fathers' work values. The study also found a distinctive pattern of work socialization such that a supportive relation with fathers predicted sons' intrinsic and people-oriented work values if the father had a professional occupation (e.g., physicians, lawyers, and college professors) but extrinsic work values if the father had a business occupation (e.g., store managers and sales persons).

Drawing on these findings, and evidence that the affective quality of parent–child relations influences children’s acceptance of parental messages (Grusec & Goodnow, 1994; Schulenberg et al., 1984; Smalls, 2009), we predicted that increases in positive mother–adolescent relations would covary with increases in adolescents' endorsement of work-related values. We also predicted that mother–adolescent relationship quality would moderate the association between mother’s socialization messages and adolescents' work-related values with a stronger association existing when the quality of mother–adolescent relations is more positive.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Participants were 245 single African American mothers and their seventh- and eighth-grade children recruited for a study of the impact of economic conditions on African American families. Data were collected between 1990 and 1991 from families living in predominantly lower socioeconomic status (SES) neighborhoods in Flint, Michigan. Because the city is characterized by a cyclical economy based primarily on the automobile industry, the city’s unemployment rate typically exceeds the national and state averages during recessions, with the city’s unemployment rates of 10.1% and 16.6% in 1988 and 2009, respectively, as compared to 5.3% and 9.3% for the national averages in 1988 and 2009, respectively (Ananich, Leighton, & Weber, 1989; Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2010). Given the city’s economic history, the present study should be viewed as one providing information about parental work socialization and its relation to adolescent work-related values within the context of high unemployment and macroeconomic decline.

The sample was recruited through a multiple-step screening procedure. First, the names were obtained of all seventh- and eighth-grade African American students in two public middle schools. If the contact parents on the school lists were female, a letter that explained the purpose of the study was mailed. A telephone screening interview was conducted with 715 mothers and legal guardians. Through this interview, 377 families in which the mother or female guardian was not married and not living with a partner were selected. Among the selected families eligible for the study, interviews were completed with 268 mothers or female legal guardians and one focal adolescent child (see McLoyd, Jayaratne, Ceballo, & Borquez, 1994 for a more detailed description of the sampling technique and recruitment procedures of the present study).

Using listwise deletion, 23 of the 268 mother–adolescent pairs were excluded from subsequent data analysis due to missing cases, leaving a total of 245 mother–adolescent pairs. Forty-five percent (n = 109) of adolescents were female. The average age of adolescents was 14.1 years (SD = .92, range = 12–16 years) and the average age of mothers was 37.4 years (SD = 7.69, range = 27–81 years). Approximately one third of mothers (37%) were employed (28% full-time and 9% part-time). Sixty-three percent were unemployed or received public assistance. A median yearly per capita family income was $2,333. Fifty-one percent of mothers had a high school diploma, whereas 11% had an associate or a bachelor’s degree.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: Mothers and focal children were interviewed in their homes. In most cases, two female interviewers as a team visited mothers and the focal child: one interviewed the mother while the other interviewed the child. Interviewers of all of the mothers and half of the children were African American interviewers, while the rest of the children were interviewed by Anglo-Americans. Mothers and focal children were interviewed separately, although this was not always possible. During the interview, questions were read aloud to the participant. The participant was given a booklet containing the response categories for all questions. Using this booklet, participants provided their response to each question, which was then recorded by the interviewer. Interviews averaged about 2 hr for the mother and 1 hr and 20 min for the child. At the end of the interview, the mother and the child were paid $25 and $10, respectively.

sec.title: Work socialization messages
sec.p: To assess mothers' work-related messages, mothers were asked how frequently they had discussions with their children to prepare them for adulthood and the transition from school to work. Mothers responded to nine different statements, using a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = never; 5 = very often). These statements were developed based on the previous literature. Exploratory factor analysis was performed on the 9 items using principal factors extraction with promax rotation. After 1 item was excluded from the race-related socialization messages because of its low loading (< .40), data were reanalyzed. Results indicated that a two-factor solution was appropriate. The two factors were interpreted as “conventional messages” and “race-related messages,” respectively.

Based on these results, two scales on socialization messages were created by averaging scores of items loading on each factor. (a) Conventional messages, a 5-item scale, assessed frequency of mothers' discussion with their children on the importance of skills, education, and training needed to obtain employment (e.g., “the education and training it takes to get into different types of jobs” and “the importance of learning skills and good work habits now while she or he is in school so that she or he can perform well in future jobs”). Internal consistency reliability coefficient (Cronbach’s alpha) was .80. Higher scores indicated greater frequency of conventional messages. (b) Race-related messages, a 3-item scale, assessed how often mothers imparted messages about the special challenges that African Americans may confront in the working world and the importance of knowing the right people to get a job (e.g., the notion that “Blacks have to work twice as hard as Whites to get ahead” and “difficulties Blacks face in finding good paying jobs”). Cronbach’s alpha was .73. Higher scores indicated higher frequency of race-related messages.

sec.title: Adolescents' work-related values
sec.p: The items utilized in the Parsons et al. study (1980) were adopted to develop two scales for this study to assess adolescents' work-related values. (a) Hard work as a determinant of work success was a 4-item scale that assessed the degree to which adolescents endorsed hard work as a determinant of work success (e.g., “Hard work is more important than good luck for a person to be successful in his or her job” and “Becoming a success is a matter of hard work; luck has little or nothing to do with it”). Adolescents responded to each item on a 6-point Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree; 6 = strongly agree). Cronbach’s alpha was .54. Higher scores indicated stronger endorsement of hard work as a determinant of work success. (b) Effort in schoolwork was measured with 6 items. Three items assessed the degree to which adolescents reported making efforts to do well in three school subjects: math, language/arts, and science (i.e., “How hard do you study for [school subject] tests?”). Adolescents responded on a 4-point Likert-type scale (1 = not hard at all; 4 = very hard). The other 3 items asked adolescents to respond to the following statement on a 5-point Likert-type scale (1 = not hard; 5 = very hard) for each of the three school subjects (i.e., “How hard are you willing to work to do extremely well in [school subject] this year?”). Because of differences in the response categories for the two sets of questions, responses were rescaled by dividing item scores by 4 for the 4-point scale items and by 5 for the 5-point scale items, respectively. Scores were then averaged across the 6 items. Cronbach’s alpha for this measure was .75. Higher scores indicated more reported effort.

sec.title: Quality of mother–adolescent relations
sec.p: Adolescents' perception of the quality of relations with their mothers was measured using a 12-item scale adapted from a scale developed by Swanson (1950). The adolescent indicated on a 6-point Likert-type scale (1 = not true at all; 6 = very true) how true 12 statements were about the nature of his or her relationship or interaction with the mother (e.g., “I feel close to my mother” and “I often have good times at home with my mother”). Cronbach’s alpha for this scale was .92. Higher scores indicated more positive mother–adolescent relations as perceived by the adolescent.

sec.title: Control variables
sec.p: We controlled for mother’s employment status, age, education level, and the focal child’s age. It was assumed that mother’s employment itself could communicate messages regarding work to adolescents, making work a more salient issue to the children. Previous studies indicate that African American mothers who were older and have higher levels of education are more likely than mothers who were younger and have lower levels of education to impart race-related socialization messages to their children (Hughes & Chen, 1997; Thornton, Chatters, Taylor, & Allen, 1990). Studies have also shown that older children receive race-related messages more from their parents (Hughes & Chen, 1997; McHale et al., 2006).

sec.title: Preliminary Analysis
sec.p: Table 1 shows the means, standard deviations, and the zero-order correlation coefficients among the study variables by sex. A series of t tests indicated no sex differences in any of the variables, except for adolescents' age and effort in schoolwork. Compared to boys, girls were slightly younger, t(208.7) = −3.02, p ≤ .01, and scored higher on reported effort in schoolwork t(243) = −3.11, p ≤ .01.

sec.p: Correlation analysis indicated that the more frequently mothers imparted conventional work socialization messages, the more strongly girls endorsed hard work as a determinant of work success, r = .30, p ≤ .01. In addition, better mother–child relation quality predicted girls' greater effort in schoolwork and stronger endorsement of hard work, r = .35, p ≤ .01 and r = .20, p ≤ .05, respectively. In contrast, for boys, neither mother’s conventional nor race-related messages was related to work-related values. However, mother–child relation quality predicted boys' work-related belief in school effort, r = .47, p ≤ .01, but not boys' endorsement of hard work as a determinant of work success.

The relation between mother’s work socialization messages and child age was also varied by child sex. For boys, child age was not associated with the frequency of either type of message. However, for girls, child age was correlated with the frequency of race-related messages. In particular, mothers directed race-related messages more frequently to older daughters than younger daughters, r = .24, p ≤ .01, whereas the frequency of conventional messages was unrelated to daughters' age. Mothers with more education communicated race-related messages to their daughters less often than did mothers with less education, r = −.20, p ≤ .05.

sec.title: Adolescents' Endorsement of Hard Work as a Determinant of Work Success
sec.p: To examine the relation of frequency of maternal socialization messages and mother–adolescent relation quality to adolescents' endorsement of hard work as a determinant of success, hierarchical multiple regression analyses were performed. Because the pattern of bivariate correlations among our major study variables differed for boys and girls (discussed above), we conducted separate hierarchical multiple regression analyses for boys and girls. Prior to regression analyses, multivariate assumptions were checked based on tests for normality of residuals and pairwise lineality. Results showed that there was no violation of the assumptions. In addition, a collinearity test based on variance inflation factor (VIF) and tolerance was conducted to examine multicollinearity among the predictor variables. Results showed that the predictors used for the subsequent analyses, including two interaction terms, had no indication of multicollinearity, VIF < 10 and tolerance > .10.

Regarding the order of the entry of variables, first, background characteristics of the mother and the focal child were entered into the regression equation (i.e., focal child’s age and mother’s employment status, age, and educational level). Then, mother’s conventional and race-related messages and adolescent reports of mother–adolescent relation quality were entered simultaneously to investigate the main effects of the variables. Finally, to test the moderating hypothesis, two interaction terms were entered into the regression equation. The interaction terms were created by multiplying each type of socialization message and quality of mother–adolescent relations. For each analysis, all predictors except dummy variables were centered prior to analysis.

Our hypothesis predicting main effects of quality of mother–adolescent relations and work socialization messages on adolescents' endorsement of hard work as a determinant of success was partially supported for boys (Table 2). Regression analyses indicated that, holding other variables constant, the more frequently mothers imparted conventional messages, the more strongly boys endorsed hard work, B = .56, p ≤ .01. Better-quality mother–adolescent relations also predicted greater endorsement of hard work among boys, B = .19, p ≤ .05. However, frequency of mothers' race-related messages was unrelated to boys' endorsement of hard work. The change in R2 from Step 1 to Step 2 was statistically significant, ΔR2 = .11, F(3, 128) = 5.66, p ≤ .001. Cohen’s f2 (Cohen, 1988) was calculated (f2 = R2AB − R2A/1 − R2AB) to estimate the effect size of the R2 change. Cohen suggests that f2 values of .02, .15, and .35 represent small, medium, and large effect sizes, respectively. The examination of this R2 change resulted in a medium effect size, f2 = .13. Among girls, neither mothers' socialization messages nor mother–daughter relation quality predicted value in hard work.

sec.p: Our hypothesis that quality of mother–adolescent relations moderates the association between maternal work socialization messages and adolescents' endorsement of hard work was not supported. The interaction terms in the regression analyses were not statistically significant for either boys or girls.

sec.title: Adolescents' Effort in Schoolwork
sec.p: We followed the same procedure described above to test our hypotheses for the second dependent variable—adolescents' effort in schoolwork. Among boys, neither type of socialization message was related to efforts in schoolwork (Table 2). However, the main effect of mother–adolescent relation quality was significant, such that the more positively boys perceived relations with their mothers, the more willing they were to work hard in school subjects, B = .08, p ≤ .0001. The change in R2 from Step 1 to Step 2 was statistically significant, ΔR2 = .15, F(3, 128) = 7.68, p ≤ .0001, f2 = .18. Contrary to prediction, quality of mother–son relations did not moderate the association between maternal messages and school effort. Similar to the findings for boys, neither type of socialization message significantly predicted girls' effort in schoolwork. However, the main effect of mother–adolescent relation quality was significant for girls, with better quality mother–adolescent relations predicting greater effort in schoolwork, B = .10, p < .0001. The change in R2 from Step 1 to Step 2 was statistically significant, ΔR2 = .23, F(3, 128) = 10.31, p ≤ .0001, f2 = .31.

Quality of mother–daughter relations significantly moderated the relation between maternal socialization messages and girls' effort in school work, ΔR2 = .10, F(2, 99) = 7.41, p ≤ .001, f2= .15. Quality of mother–daughter relations significantly moderated the association between conventional messages and girls' school effort, B = .13, p ≤ .01. To interpret this moderating effect of mother–daughter relations, simple slope tests were conducted. As consistent with our hypothesis, in the context of more positive mother–daughter relations, the more frequently mothers communicated conventional messages, the greater effort girls made in schoolwork, B = .49, p ≤ 05. However, in the context of less positive mother–daughter relations, higher frequency of conventional messages was associated with diminished school effort, B = −.54, p ≤ .01.

Quality of mother–adolescent relations also significantly moderated the association between mothers' race-related socialization messages and girls' effort in schoolwork, B = −.11, p ≤ .0001, but the nature of this moderating effect was contrary to our prediction. Simple slope tests revealed that in the context of more positive mother–daughter relations, higher frequency of race-related messages was associated with lower effort in schoolwork, B = −.42, p ≤ .001. In contrast, in the context of less positive relations, more frequent race-related messages predicted greater effort in schoolwork, B = .48, p ≤ .0001.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: There is a strong belief among Americans that poverty, wealth, and economic inequality in general derive largely from differences in individual-level motivation and the degree to which individuals have internalized the value of hard work (Harrah & Friedman, 1990; Kluege & Smith, 1986). Although a rich body of research documents determinants of students' achievement motivation (Eccles, Wigfield, & Schiefele, 1998), research has identified relatively few antecedents of children and adolescents' internalization of the work ethic, that is, the notion that hard work is essential to occupational and economic success. The present study represents a step toward filling this gap.

Although we found no main effect of maternal race-related messages on either adolescents' school effort or endorsement of hard work, an important contribution of the present study is its expansion of racial socialization to encompass messages pertaining specifically to work life. Previous studies of racial socialization have tended to focus on broad race-related messages that are not context specific. The lack of relationship in the present study between maternal race-related messages and adolescents' work-related values may signal that the strength and nature of the association is conditional on factors not examined in the present study. Alternatively, our null finding may have resulted because the seventh and eighth graders in our study are too immature cognitively to process the messages their mothers are imparting about the potential impact of racial barriers on future job opportunities. With increased maturity and growth in racial identity processes (Phinney, 1990), these adolescents may become more susceptible to the messages their mothers are sending them about racial barriers in the labor market.

The present study found partial support for our hypothesis that derived from Mickelson’s (1990) conception of concrete and abstract attitudes. Conventional work socialization messages did not predict adolescents' reported work-related values, except for boys' value in hard work as a determinant of work success. This pattern of null findings suggests that accentuating education, skills, and good work habits as prerequisites for job success may not be sufficient to enhance the school efforts of African American adolescents from low-income families. In this regard, mothers' conventional socialization messages, similar to the abstract attitudes conceptualized by Mickelson, may not fit their children’s perceptions of their realities, and therefore, may not be viewed as useful in preparing them for work or career success.

However, consistent with prior research (e.g., Mortimer & Kumka, 1982), we found that African American adolescents with more positive relations with their mothers reportedly made greater efforts to do well academically. Moreover, among girls, but not boys, quality of mother–adolescent relations moderated the link between maternal conventional messages and adolescent school effort. This moderating effect suggests that girls devote greater efforts to academic endeavors when conventional messages about the importance of skills, education, and training needed to obtain good employment are imparted in the context of higher levels of maternal support, encouragement, and affection. In short, girls are more likely to internalize conventional values about the importance of education and behave in accord with those values when they have good relations with their mothers. The reason that a comparable moderating effect was not found among boys is unclear and a question that warrants further study.

Another perplexing finding in the present study is the moderating effect of quality of mother–adolescent relations on the link between race-related messages and girls' efforts in schoolwork. Contrary to prediction, it was in the context of less positive mother–daughter relations, not in the context of more positive mother–daughter relations, that race-related messages were associated with stronger school effort among girls. A possible explanation can be that girls who are devoting little effort to their schoolwork or who are not doing well in school may have strained relations with their mothers precisely for these reasons. By emphasizing the special challenges that await African American youth who do poorly in school, mothers may attempt to dissuade this pattern of behavior and cultivate more conscientiousness about schoolwork in their daughters. These girls may be most responsive to messages about racial barriers because their level of effort in schoolwork was low to begin with. These speculations, however, need to be examined in future research.

sec.title: Implications for Career Development Theory and Counseling
sec.p: Our findings underscore the role of parents in the development of adolescents' work-related values, as more harmonious mother–adolescent relations predicted stronger endorsement of hard work as a determinant of work success among boys and greater willingness to invest in academic work among both boys and girls. One implication of these findings pertains to parental involvement in adolescents' preparation for future employment and careers. Career counselors working in prevention and intervention programs and other contexts may be more effective in helping low-income adolescents identify career goals, identify plans for reaching those goals, and develop a more positive future orientation when they actively involve parents in this process, especially if the parent–adolescent relationship is close and harmonious.

Involving low-income parents in their adolescents' explorations of employment and career options and in the subsequent planning process offers opportunities not only to develop beneficial alliances with parents but to positively affect parents' work-related perceptions, attitudes, and knowledge to increase parents' awareness of their influence on the adolescent’s future orientation and career development and to discuss strategies that potentially enhance the likelihood that youth will receive the messages that parents intend to impart. Having single mothers become involved successfully in career counseling for their adolescent children can be achieved through individual guidance sessions or in a group format such as workshops, evening parent meetings, or short-term parent programs. Regardless of the format that may be adopted, however, in order to create opportunities to work with these mothers, the career counselor needs to become sensitive to a variety of life situations and negative experiences that single-mother African Americans tend to face. For example, single-mothers' lives tend to be significantly influenced by their severe financial and job situations, which could cause the mothers to lack time in interacting with their children actively for school matters and develop negative physical (e.g., chronic fatigue) and psychological health (e.g., depression and anxiety). The counselor also needs to consider the significant influences that those experiences have on these mothers' ability to become actively involved in activities held at their child’s school. Many single parents may experience unfavorable reactions at school, such as prejudice from teachers (Colpin, Vandemeulebroecke, & Ghessquiere, 2004). These negative experiences that single-mothers tend to have are considered barriers for these parents to have involved at school and a source of their unwillingness to involve in activities at school (Colpin et al., 2004).

African American parents, particularly from impoverished families, are less involved in their child’s school, compared to European American parents (Hill & Craft, 2003). Therefore, single-mother African Americans may particularly be less willing to approach or collaborate with career counselors regarding their children’s career issues. It is imperative for career counselors to enhance sensitivity to single-mother African Americans' experiences in order to encourage their active involvement.

sec.title: Study Limitations and Future Directions
sec.p: Caution must be exercised in interpreting the findings of the present study because of several limitations. First and most significantly, the current study is limited in terms of the psychometric properties of our measures. Measures with higher reliability and established validity would provide a more rigorous test of the study’s hypothesis, as would use of different informants about mother–adolescent relationship quality, and multiple indicators of adolescent outcomes. Second, data were collected from single mothers and their adolescents residing in economically disadvantaged neighborhoods. The study’s findings may not apply to African American households that have different family structures and higher SES. Besides, the data for the present study were collected several years ago. The demographic make-up of the city in which the data were collected and the schools from which participants were recruited has been fairly stable over the years. In addition, the city’s economic climate continues to be unfavorable, relative to other cities in Michigan and to the nation as a whole. Thus, there is no reason to believe that the opportunity structure within the employment sector has changed fundamentally. For these reasons, we believe that our findings are generalizable to low-income, single-mother African American families currently residing in the city, but caution is warranted nevertheless. Finally, the present study’s cross-sectional design does not allow us to claim any causal relations among variables. Experimental methods would be useful in determining the impact of different types of work-related messages on youth’s beliefs and attitudes and identifying the mechanisms through which different types of messages exert their influence.

In summary, the present study examined the effect of single-mother African Americans' socialization messages regarding work on adolescents' work-related values of hard work and effort in schoolwork. The results indicated the effects of mothers' socialization messages on adolescents' work-related values were moderated by adolescents' sex and their perceptions of relationship quality with their parents. These findings suggest that single-mother African Americans' socialization messages may have different effects on adolescent’s values of work, depending on the context in which those messages are communicated to adolescent children. More studies are needed to better understand processes through which adolescents from single-parent families, including African American families, may be socialized through socialization messages from parents regarding not only values, beliefs, and motivation in their future work life but also their career aspirations and significant decisions regarding career choice.
